Package org.opensextant.giscore.input.kml

Class KmlInputStream

java.lang.Object
org.opensextant.giscore.input.GISInputStreamBase
org.opensextant.giscore.input.XmlInputStream
org.opensextant.giscore.input.kml.KmlInputStream
All Implemented Interfaces:
Closeable, AutoCloseable, IGISInputStream, IKml
public class KmlInputStream extends XmlInputStream implements IKml
Read a Google Earth Keyhole Markup Language (KML) file in as an input stream one event at a time.

Supports KML 2.0 through KML 2.2 data formats with allowance for sloppy or lax KML files as would be allowed in Google Earth. Limited support is provided for Google's KML Extensions with gx prefix and ... namespace . Strict conformance to the KML 2.2 specification is maintained in output in the associated KmlOutputStream class. In doing so some "legacy" KML 2.0 or KML 2.1 conventions may be normalized into the equivalent 2.2 form or dropped if not supported.

Each time the read method is called, the code tries to read a single event's worth of data. Generally that is one of the following events:

  • A new container returning a ContainerStart object
  • Exiting a container returning a ContainerEnd object
  • A new feature returning a Feature object

Supports KML Placemark, GroundOverlay, ScreenOverlay, NetworkLink, Document, and Folder elements with limited/partial support for the lesser used NetworkLinkControl(*), and PhotoOverlay(*) elements.

Geometry support includes: Point, LineString, LinearRing, Polygon, MultiGeometry, and Model(*).

Supported KML properties include: name, address(*), description, open, visibility, Camera/LookAt, atom:author, atom:link, xal:AddressDetails, phoneNumber(*), styleUrl, inline/shared Styles, Region, Snippet, snippet, ExtendedData(*), Schema, TimeStamp/TimeSpan elements in addition to the geometry are parsed and set on the Feature object.

Style and StyleMap supported on Features (Placemarks, Documents, Folders, etc.) with IconStyle, PolyStyle, ListStyle, etc. StyleMaps with inline Styles are supported. StyleMaps must specify styleUrl and/or inline Style. Nested StyleMaps are not supported.

If elements (e.g. Style or StyleMap) are out of order on input that same order is preserved in the order of elements returned in read(). For example, if Style/StyleMap elements appear incorrectly out of order such as after the firstFeature element then it will likewise be out of order. This will not be corrected by KmlWriter or KmlOutputStream, which assumes the caller writes those elements in a valid order. It should still work with Google Earth but it will not conform to the KML 2.2 spec.

If debug logging mode is enabled for this class, the following additional validations will be checked and logged as warnings:

  • ATC 3: Geometry coordinates: Whitespace found within coordinate tuple
  • ATC 14: Point [OGC-07-147r2: cl. 10.3.2]: Check that the kml:coordinates element in a kml:Point geometry contains exactly one coordinate tuple.
  • ATC 15: LineString [OGC-07-147r2: cl. 10.7.3.4.1]: Verify that the kml:coordinates element in a kml:LineString geometry contains at least two coordinate tuples.
  • ATC 16: LinearRing - control points: LinearRing geometry must contain at least 4 coordinate tuples, where the first and last are identical.
  • ATC 26: Schema - SimpleField: Verify the SimpleField value of the 'type' attribute is one of the allowable data types

Notes/Limitations:

  • The actual handling of containers and other features has some uniform methods. Every feature in KML can have a set of common attributes and additional elements.
  • Geometry is handled by common code as well. All coordinates in KML are transmitted as tuples of two or three elements. The formatting of these is consistent and is handled internally. Tessellate, extrude, altitudeMode and gx:drawOrder properties are maintained on the associated Geometry.
  • phoneNumber and address fields do not explicitly exist on the Feature or Common object but are added as an Element with the http://www.opengis.net/kml/2.2 namespace. Access by calling getElements() on the feature.
  • ExtendedData Handles ExtendedData with Data/Value or SchemaData/SimpleData elements including the non-KML namespace form of extended data for arbitrary XML data (see http://code.google.com/apis/kml/documentation/extendeddata.html#opaquedata). Only a single Data/SchemaData/Schema ExtendedData mapping is assumed per Feature but note that although uncommon, KML allows features to define multiple Schemas. Features with mixed Data and/or multiple SchemaData elements will be associated only with the last Schema referenced.
  • Unsupported deprecated tags include: Metadata, which is consumed but ignored.
  • Some support for gx KML extensions (e.g. Track, MultiTrack, Tour, etc.). Also gx:altitudeMode is handle specially and stored as a value of the altitudeMode in LookAt, Camera, Geometry, and GroundOverlay.
  • PhotoOverlay Limited support for PhotoOverlay which creates an basic overlay object with Point and rotation without retaining other PhotoOverlay-specific properties (ViewVolume, ImagePyramid, or shape).
  • Model Limited support for Model geometry type. Keeps only location and altitude properties.
  • "NetworkLinkControl" Limited support for NetworkLinkControl which creates an object wrapper for the link with the top-level info but the update details (i.e. Create, Delete, and Change) are discarded.
  • IconStyle and LineStyle are fully supported except for colorMode = random which is ignored. Only PolyStyle has support for the random colorMode.
  • Allows timestamps to omit seconds field as does Google Earth. Strict XML schema validation requires seconds field in the dateTime (YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ) format but Google Earth is lax in its parsing rules. Likewise allows the 'Z' suffix to be omitted in which case it defaults to UTC.
Author:
J.Mathews

    • parseCoord

      @NotNull public static @NotNull List<Point> parseCoord(String coord)
      Coordinate parser that matches the loose parsing of coordinates in Google Earth. KML reference states "Do not include spaces within a [coordinate] tuple" yet Google Earth allows whitespace to appear anywhere in the input or commas to appear between tuples (e.g., 1,2,3,4,5,6 -> 1,2,3 4,5,6).

      • Simple state machine parsing keeps track of what part of the coordinate had been found so far.
      • Extra whitespace is allowed anywhere in the string.
      • Invalid text in input is ignored.
      Parameters:
      coord - Coordinate string
      Returns:
      list of coordinates. Returns empty list if no coordinates are valid, never null
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - error if lat/lon coordinate values are out of range
